posts.name: Navneet Vikram Tey
posts.cooked:
Restore Privacy ‚Äì 20 Oct 22

Timing Attacks on WhatsApp, Signal, and Threema can Reveal User Location

Researchers found it's possible to infer the locations of users of WhatsApp, Signal, and Threema by the delivery status notifications.

Est. reading time: 5 minutes

Article does mention : Two of the named messengers have told RestorePrivacy via email (on October 20th) that they are investigating the situation and will provide a comment on the report shortly.

I am hoping Signal is one of them

link_counts.title: Timing Attacks on WhatsApp, Signal, and Threema can Reveal User Location | RestorePrivacy
Better security against sidechannel- and protocol-attacks (DEFCON 2025 security-flaws)
[Security] Dont send delivery confirmations for incorrectly formatted messages

posts.cooked:
First of all: what is this clickbait title?! It‚Äôs obviously not possible to determine anyone‚Äôs location, as in GPS, using the method described in the paper!

tl;dr
They basically determined that if you send tens of thousands of messages over the course of several weeks and record the time message delivery confirmations take (using Wireshark) to your victim while you know where they currently are (home, gym, woods, etc.) - you can then analyze that data and in the future deduce if they are at home, gym or in the woods‚Ä¶
Additionally, if you message multiple victims you would similarly be able to determine whether they are in the same city/country as you, or on the other side of the Globe. There‚Äôs nothing to be worried about and even the authors of this ingenious paper (sarcasm!) admit that ‚ÄúSimilarly, traffic analysis, is [‚Ä¶] used to analyze encrypted network traffic in various other domains. Purposes include [‚Ä¶] deanonymizing users [‚Ä¶] in anonymity networks such as Tor with the most recent ones technically reaching accuracy of up to 100 % using deep learning techniques.‚Äù

I‚Äôm currently writing more detailed explanation of what this paper is about, but that‚Äôs just a tl;dr for now. Writing such paper is just so dumb‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm waiting for other platforms, not mentioned in it, to try and capitalize on it‚Ä¶

More details:

Alright, so what do they say about their discovery:

We presented a novel timing side-channel in popular instant messengers, allowing to distinguish different receivers and their locations by sending them instant messages. We have demonstrated how measuring the time between sending a message and receiving the notification that the message has been delivered enables clients to spy on each other, e.g., to determine whether or not they are at their usual location.

Right, but how easy in practice would that be‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs see:

In an initial training phase, the adversary sends messages to the victim and learns timing characteristics while knowing their whereabouts.

Ok, but how many messages exactly?

In a single experiment iteration, the phone subsequently sends a series of five messages [‚Ä¶] The first four messages are short and only consist of a single word each, while the last message is a whole text paragraph. We send the first four messages at an interval of 10 seconds to allow for the confirmations to arrive before sending the next message, while we increase the waiting time before the last messages to 20 seconds in order to accommodate the longer time it takes to type the long text, thus facilitating the analysis of the packet captures. [‚Ä¶] We repeat this procedure over a period of several weeks [‚Ä¶] Whereas the physical locations of receiving devices remain unchanged throughout the Round 1 measurements, we collect data for at least one week for each location a receiving device was placed at in Round 2. In total, we use more than 240,000 messages sent during the two rounds of experiments for evaluation.

If I‚Äôm talking to someone that frequently, it‚Äôs safe to assume they either way know where I live/work/whatever‚Ä¶

And the authors admit that:

Since the attack entails sending messages, the adversary‚Äôs behavior might be observed by the victim and appear suspicious. Therefore, the attacker might leverage timings of messages they send anyway which would, however, narrow down the practical threat scope to people who regularly exchange larger numbers of messages.

No, VPNs or Tor wouldn‚Äôt help‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs something seriously wrong with those results - Tor performs worse than VPN, accuracy varies that much between apps, etc. But they only tested one VPN server‚Ä¶ and then there‚Äôs Tor routes/nodes variability to consider‚Ä¶ No, just no. Take that with a grain of salt:

We run a small additional experiment to get a preliminary estimate of the effects of using a VPN as a countermeasure. [‚Ä¶] Connected to a US-based VPN server provided by a commercial VPN provider. Whereas without VPN, the network connection of this device can be distinguished with up to 90% accuracy, classifications perform worse when using a VPN. For Threema (51%) and WhatsApp (62%), performance is hardly better than random guessing (50 %). However, for Signal, we reach a surprisingly high overall accuracy of 77 %. When repeating the same small experiment with using Tor instead of a VPN, WiFi and cellular connections can be distinguished better (Signal: 72 %, Threema: 58 %, WhatsApp: 82 %).
Without investigating these issues more systematically, we can only speculate about the reasons. One explanation could be that Signal‚Äôs servers are US-based and, therefore, the routing overhead introduced by using the VPN server is too small to adequately perturb timings.



We got in contact with the providers of the messenger apps (Signal, Threema, WhatsApp) and reported the vulnerability to them prior to the submission of this paper in May 2022. Whereas Signal and WhatsApp have not acknowledged the issue to date (October 2022)

There‚Äôs nothing new to acknowledge‚Ä¶ and even Tor is vulnerable to traffic analysis, so I guess we should go back to caves?

(And I would argue this isn‚Äôt even traffic analysis in the traditional sense. It‚Äôs more of a differential analysis, that‚Äôs very limited in practical use.)




If you want to write a similar paper, here‚Äôs a protip for you: you can determine in which time-zone someone is using traffic analysis! Wow, it‚Äôs such a breakthrough in privacy research!
Gotta love the academia‚Ä¶ they have such realistic attack scenarios‚Ä¶ like GhostTouch

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked: Just add a random delay of a few ms to these notifications and the attack is disarmed.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: This is a nothing story. Just use a VPN like it says at the end of the article.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: Btw if you would just add a few random ms, how would that help? The attacker could just send many messages and correct for the randomised delays by getting an average no?

Attack and Countermeasure Evaluation. We demon-
strate to what extent we can distinguish different receivers and their respective locations from each other based on the measured delivery notification timings. We also show that this threat can be mitigated by randomly delaying delivery notifications in the range of a few seconds.

‚Ä¶ randomly delaying delivery notifications ‚Ä¶

random delays in another context:

Remove read-receipt functionality for better security Feature Requests
Read receipts double the amount of data available for statistical attacks on Signal (as described in https://cs-people.bu.edu/kaptchuk/publications/ndss21.pdf). Removing receipts, or even defaulting to off with a warning in the settings panel, would improve Signal security.

and from the linked pdf (there):

Random delays. Users could send delivery or read receipts after a random delay, making it harder for attackers to correlate messages. This forces an attacker to increase the epoch duration to perform the same attack. We analyze the effect of varying epoch duration in Figure 5, and find that even with hour-long epochs‚Äîlikely rendering delivery receipts useless‚Äîusers could still be identified within 60 messages. We conclude that injecting random delays is an ineffective way to achieve anonymity.

although due to other reasons and limited only to groups:

Turn off delivery and read receipts by default in large groups Feature Requests
As a data point, I was offline for 36 hours and after coming online the client had to process 5870 messages which took 30 mins or so. There were 150 Media messages, 235 Text messages, 150 reactions. The shocker is 4625 delivery receipts and 445 read receipts. This is 86% of the messages that were to be processed. Read receipts seem to be batched up quite a bit compared to delivery receipts. In large groups all this traffic is almost always pointless. For those groups where this is needed, peop‚Ä¶

EDIT:
see alsio Herohtar‚Äôs comment:

If anything, you should be requesting that delivery receipts be disabled,

posts.name: ClauZ
posts.cooked:
This is still a feasible method of tracking somebody right ?..

And it‚Äôs especially problematic for people that use phones without play services, since on those phones, Signal has an always active websocket connection to the server ‚Ä¶

Am I right ? or has something changed that mitigates this ?

I gave up on expecting an actual answer from anybody @Signal so, if anybody is aware of any mitigations put in place, feel free to educate me

Was there ever any progress made with this?

My Problem is not really user location, but rather that based on the timing of the delivery status notification it is possible to tell if someone has their phone turned on / if they have Signal opened.. which is information that (1) I don‚Äôt want to have for my own mental health and (2) don‚Äôt want anyone else to have.

I actually observed this independently from this topic and the paper and I think that this is really unfortunate..
